years in Harvard and then

1302.05.text:
you decided that you
wanted to go to Florida

1304.05.text:
how'd you get
involved with FAU?

1305.77.text:
CHARLES HENNEKENS: Well I
spent thirty years in New

1308.46.text:
York except for
the year at Wharton,

1310.86.text:
thirty in Boston except
for the year in Oxford and

1313.49.text:
now I'm trying to
spend thirty in Florida.

1316.30.text:
I moved to Boca Raton
again my mother was there,

1319.55.text:
my aunt was there and I
kind of took care of them

1323.19.text:
for the last couple of
decades of their lives and

1327.91.text:
I was sort of semi
retiring and I was able to

1335.16.text:
do some research at
the then Charles E.

1341.35.text:
And then about four
years ago the Charles E.

1345.00.text:
Schmidt College of medical
science became the Charles E.

1348.56.text:
Schmidt College of
Medicine and we will be

1351.25.text:
graduating our first class of
students in this coming spring.

1358.11.text:
And I'm astonished at the
outstanding qualities of these

1363.29.text:
They have grade point
averages of about 3.8,

1366.46.text:
board scores of about 32
and they're outstanding

1370.30.text:
young men and women who I
think will do a lot too,

1377.04.text:
MICHAEL STOLER: You've
written over 865 articles.

1383.10.text:
MICHAEL STOLER: You
still play tennis?

1384.21.text:
CHARLES HENNEKENS: Well my
job in terms of the first

1389.80.text:
Sir Richard Doll professor
and senior academic

1392.21.text:
advisor to the Dean has
morphed into what we call

1396.72.text:
dash board indicators
of academic success,

1399.64.text:
so I'm mentoring a lot
of the students and young

1402.67.text:
faculty on a one on one basis
with the goal of trying to

1406.73.text:
achieve these milestones in
academic medicine that will

1410.61.text:
improve the reputation of their
outstanding medical school.

1414.76.text:
MICHAEL STOLER: Are you still
doing

1417.35.text:
CHARLES HENNEKENS: I am,
I'm doing some of it at

1419.89.text:
FAU, some at Harvard,
some at the University of

1422.97.text:
Wisconsin and some at
Meharry Medical College

1425.49.text:
where we're trying to
reduce disparities in

1428.42.text:
health between racial
disparities which are large.

1433.28.text:
MICHAEL STOLER:
And any more books?

1435.27.text:
CHARLES HENNEKENS: Not in
the offing at the present time.

1439.19.text:
MICHAEL STOLER: Now you've
traveled around the world

1441.97.text:
we have pictures
of you in China or.

1446.50.text:
MICHAEL STOLER: I mean
so tell me about some of

1449.19.text:
these trips the
reasons for them and.

1451.79.text:
CHARLES HENNEKENS:
Well I was part of an

1454.46.text:
international contingent
that was the first group

1458.32.text:
to go to parts of
China since 1949,

1461.90.text:
we went shortly after
my Mao died around 1981,

1465.88.text:
our host was Dr. Lee Bing
who was the daughter of

1468.46.text:
Premier and was the head
of the Chinese Academy of

1473.41.text:
Sciences and we helped
them design studies and

1476.74.text:
Lin Shan in the Honan
province that showed the

1480.55.text:
beneficial effects of the
combination of antioxidant

1483.82.text:
vitamins in reducing risks
of stomach and esophageal

1488.07.text:
cancer in this poorly
nourished population,

1491.20.text:
that had one of the
highest risks in the world.

1493.29.text:
MICHAEL STOLER: So let's
talk about family.

1498.75.text:
CHARLES HENNEKENS: Well I
have three children and my

1506.28.text:
my older daughter is a
teacher and a coach and my

1509.22.text:
last daughter is a psycho
therapist and a teacher as well.

1516.24.text:
MICHAEL STOLER: And how
many grandchildren do you have?

1518.62.text:
CHARLES HENNEKENS: Four,
Grace Madeline Hennekens the

1521.81.text:
daughter of Chuck Hennekens who
lives in Plantation, Florida.

1526.81.text:
And then there are
Ella Caroline Duffy,

1529.69.text:
Hayden Cole Duffy and my
namesake Charlotte Adele

1535.60.text:
MICHAEL STOLER: Right, we have
the pictures of the Duffys over

1539.64.text:
so you know the joke was
your mother would have

1541.63.text:
been happy that you
became a physician,

1543.78.text:
but you never, you
know you never practiced.

1547.62.text:
I mean you know,
you've never been.

1549.67.text:
CHARLES HENNEKENS: That
is true I remember this

1553.14.text:
colleague and friend of
mine Tim Johnson did a

1555.28.text:
20/20 piece on me and it
was taped and she saw it

1558.62.text:
and she thought I looked
good.

1559.75.text: She said you have a great

1560.75.text:
smile just like your dad, but
tell me is there any chance

1564.42.text:
you'll ever be a
real doctor again.

1567.34.text:
Well the reality is that
once I've accepted the

1569.99.text:
reality that it's far
better to be over the hill

1572.45.text:
than under the hill my
life has been the best ever.

1575.69.text:
It's the quality of my
life is outstanding,

1578.35.text:
I feel so fortunate to be
at the Schmidt College of

1581.89.text:
Medicine and mentoring
these outstanding young

1584.01.text:
people, not just the students
but the junior faculty as well.

1588.27.text:
I get to play tennis
virtually every day

1591.81.text:
although with my work I've
now playing nights and

1594.95.text:
weekends rather than
during the day but I'm

1598.85.text:
having the
time of my life.

1600.46.text:
I'm fortunate to have Caroline
Yang in my life who I think

1606.24.text:
is just has one of the best
hearts of anyone I've ever met.

1610.56.text:
My life is just the best
it's ever been and I hope

1613.11.text:
it stays this
way for a while.

1616.22.text:
I got to give you the
Brooklyn Queens and the

1619.96.text:
boy who spent and had a
lot of honors at Queens

1622.86.text:
College you know has
joined me today to tell

1629.11.text:
CHARLES HENNEKENS: Thank you so
much Michel, it's a pleasure.
